posts.post_content:
@brothersbutler:  
  
Your opponent's [Leyline of Sanctity](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Leyline of Sanctity) forbids you to even target him. This means that you can't even cast a [Fireball](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Fireball) with that player among its targets. So [Leyline of Punishment](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Leyline of Punishment) does nothing in this case. **But**, it does make non-targeted spells' damage unpreventable (for example, you can cast a [Volcanic Fallout](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Volcanic Fallout) and it will deal damage and kill creatures with toughness up to 2, even if they have protection from it)
posts.html:

posts.post_content:
@Donovan\_Fabian: You're taking that short-sighted viewpoint of "This can be removed, so it's pointless." If you find that to be an issue, build a deck out of Shroud and/or invulnerability effects. If you have a deck made solely out of cards that an opponent would use removal on, I very much doubt they'd have enough removal to get rid of it all; and this thing can come into play pre-game, where there is surprisingly little removal. Besides, the point to it is not just the life gain, but the damage prevent; this is obviously hand-tailored to a burn deck, which- o hey look!- means a red one.
  
   
To be honest, it pales in comparison to most of the other Leylines (besides [Leyline of Lightning](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Leyline of Lightning), leading me to believe the inventor of the Leylines just plain didn't like red), but this is just plain a good (not great) card that should find a place in any burn deck.
posts.html:

Besides, the point to it is not just the life gain, but the damage prevent; this is obviously hand-tailored to a burn deck, which- o hey look!- means a red one.

To be honest, it pales in comparison to most of the other Leylines (besides Leyline of Lightning, leading me to believe the inventor of the Leylines just plain didn't like red), but this is just plain a good (not great) card that should find a place in any burn deck.

posts.post_content:
This finds a home nicely in RDW, indeed. It's far from the best of the Leylines. None of them are "garbage." This one is more of a situational/sideboard type card.  
Leyline of Punishment effectively robs [Baneslayer Angel](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Baneslayer Angel) and its ilk of lifelink and prevents abuse of certain combos e.g. [Necropotence](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Necropotence) or [Yawgmoth's Bargain](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Yawgmoth's Bargain) with [Ivory Tower](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Ivory Tower), or [Phyrexian Processor](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Phyrexian Processor) with [Angelic Chorus](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Angelic Chorus). This nips any of that something-for-nothing shenanigans in the bud. It also messes with life manipulation trickery like [Soul Conduit](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Soul Conduit).  
What's that, a [Mark of Asylum](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mark of Asylum) so I can't bolt your creatures? Well, I've got something for that right here.  
Are they hiding behind creatures with protection from red? Now you can burn 'em.  
It has no meaningful drawback in a mono-red deck, and blue isn't much hindered by it either.  
This Leyline also puts a crack in... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

This nips any of that something-for-nothing shenanigans in the bud. It also messes with life manipulation trickery like Soul Conduit.
What's that, a Mark of Asylum so I can't bolt your creatures? Well, I've got something for that right here.
Are they hiding behind creatures with protection from red? Now you can burn 'em.
It has no meaningful drawback in a mono-red deck, and blue isn't much hindered by it either.

posts.post_content:
Protections uses the word 'prevent' and this stops the word 'prevent'. Hence this stops protection, in that specific instance. All other effects of protection still hold true.  
  
@SoulShatter  
You are correct that in some sense it does make damage 'incapable' of hitting the target. But I'm afraid mtg is very specific when it comes to semantics. The specific word used in the rule book is 'prevent'. You probably were taught by someone that maybe paraphrased the rules so it's understandable, but at a Tournament environment, the specific wording is important.   
  
A good rule of thumb for mtg is if one source says that something CAN happen and another says it CANNOT, always go with the CANNOT case. There may be a few weird exceptions to this, but I can't think of one off hand.  
  
Think of [Wrath of God](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Wrath of God), it says 'destroy' all creatures. Regenerate says to replace all instances of the word 'destroy' along with remove damage, etc. But Wrath also denies regeneration. Negative effec... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
posts.html:
Protections uses the word 'prevent' and this stops the word 'prevent'. Hence this stops protection, in that specific instance. All other effects of protection still hold true.

@SoulShatter
You are correct that in some sense it does make damage 'incapable' of hitting the target. But I'm afraid mtg is very specific when it comes to semantics. The specific word used in the rule book is 'prevent'. You probably were taught by someone that maybe paraphrased the rules so it's understandable, but at a Tournament environment, the specific wording is important.

A good rule of thumb for mtg is if one source says that something CAN happen and another says it CANNOT, always go with the CANNOT case. There may be a few weird exceptions to this, but I can't think of one off hand.

Think of Wrath of God, it says 'destroy' all creatures. Regenerate says to replace all instances of the word 'destroy' along with remove damage, etc. But Wrath also denies regeneration. Negative effec... (see all)

Posted By: OmegaSerris (6/30/2011 11:13:35 PM)

posts.post_content:
@brothersbutler  
Refer to boshewics post for the relevant rule:   
Protection uses prevention for damage and thusly this leyline means that protection will no longer prevent the damage. This doesn't make protection useless or something as it still prevents targeting and sacrifices enchantments of that color that become attached to it, AND it still can't be blocked by those colors. What it loses is the ability to block those colors without taking damage, or block damage from board sweepers etc...   
  
I.E. If I attack with a [spark elemental](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=spark elemental) with this out and the enemy blocks with [progenitus](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=progenitus), I can then [Blood Frenzy](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Blood Frenzy), [Double Cleave](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Double Cleave) and successfully kill it with my 10 damage.
posts.html:
@brothersbutler
Refer to boshewics post for the relevant rule:
Protection uses prevention for damage and thusly this leyline means that protection will no longer prevent the damage. This doesn't make protection useless or something as it still prevents targeting and sacrifices enchantments of that color that become attached to it, AND it still can't be blocked by those colors. What it loses is the ability to block those colors without taking damage, or block damage from board sweepers etc...

I.E. If I attack with a spark elemental with this out and the enemy blocks with progenitus, I can then Blood Frenzy, Double Cleave and successfully kill it with my 10 damage.

posts.post_content:
Falgorn is correct. Refer to rule 702.14, "Protection."  
  
702.14e Any damage that would be dealt by sources that have the stated quality to a permanent or  
player with protection is prevented.  
  
[Pyroclasm](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Pyroclasm ) will kill a [Kor Firewalker](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Kor Firewalker ) with [Leyline of Punishment](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Leyline of Punishment) on the board.
posts.html:
